raw_text:
Italy 17-28 Ireland
 
 Two moments of magic from Brian O'Driscoll guided Ireland to a workmanlike victory against Italy.
 
 A pair of classic outside breaks from the Ireland captain set up tries for Geordan Murphy and Peter Stringer. Italy led 9-8 early in the second half but Stringer's try gave Ireland a lead they never lost. The hosts cut the gap to 18-12 with 10 minutes left and nearly scored through Ludovico Nitoglia, but Denis Hickie's try ensured an Irish victory. Italy came flying out of the blocks and took the lead through a Luciano Orquera penalty after seven minutes.
 
 It could have been better for the hosts but the fly-half missed two kickable penalties and Ireland drew level with a Ronan O'Gara penalty midway through the first half. The Italians were driving at the heart of the Irish defence and, for the first quarter, the Irish pack struggled to secure any ball for their talented backs.
 
 When they finally did, just before the half-hour mark, O'Driscoll promptly created a sparkling try for Murphy. The Ireland captain ran a dummy scissors and made a magical outside break before drawing the full-back and putting the diving Murphy in at the corner. O'Gara missed the twice-taken conversion and the visitors found themselves trailing once again. Roland de Marigny took over the kicking duties for Italy from the hapless Orquera, and he landed a penalty either side of the break to edge Italy into a 9-8 lead.
 
 The only Ireland player offering a real threat was O'Driscoll, and it was his break that set up the second try for the visitors. Shane Horgan threw an overhead pass as he was about to be forced into touch and Stringer scooted over, with O'Gara landing the tricky conversion. A penalty apiece saw Ireland leading 18-12 as the game entered the final quarter, but they were lucky to survive when Italy launched a series of attacks. Winger Nitoglia dropped the ball as he reached for the line and Italy nearly rumbled over from a driving maul.
 
 An O'Gara penalty put Ireland more than a converted try ahead and they made the game safe when Hickie latched onto an inside pass from Murphy and crossed for a converted try. O'Driscoll limped off late on, joining centre partner Gordon D'Arcy on the sidelines, and the final word went to Italy. Prop Martin Castrogiovanni powered over for a try which was fitting reward for an Italian pack which had kept the Irish under pressure throughout.
 
 De Marigny; Mi Bergamasco, Canale, Masi, Nitoglia; Orquera, Troncon; Lo Cicero, Ongaro, Castrogiovanni; Dellape, Bortolami; Persico, Ma Bergamasco, Parisse.
 
 Perugini, Intoppa, Del Fava, Dal Maso, Griffen, Pozzebon, Robertson.
 
 Murphy, Horgan, O'Driscoll, D'Arcy, Hickie, O'Gara, Stringer, Corrigan, Byrne, Hayes, O'Kelly, O'Connell, S Easterby, Leamy, Foley.
 
 Sheahan, Horan, O'Callaghan, Miller, G Easterby, Humphreys, Dempsey.
 
 P O'Brien (New Zealand)
llama3.2:3b: Italy 17-28 Ireland. Ireland won despite Italy's strong start, with tries from Geordan Murphy and Peter Stringer setting up a convincing victory after Italy had taken the lead. Ireland captain Brian O'Driscoll made two crucial breaks, including one that set up Murphy's try. Denis Hickie sealed the win for Ireland with a late converted try, while Italy nearly scored through Ludovico Nitoglia in injury time.
gemma2:2b:
Ireland defeated Italy 28-17. Brian O'Driscoll scored two tries and helped set up other tries for his teammates. Ireland led by a penalty but Italy led 9-8 early in the second half. 
Italy had more opportunities, but their attempts were blocked.  Denis Hickie then made a crucial try, giving Ireland a secure lead.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Ireland won the match against Italy 18-9. The game involved two main periods: a breakaway set up by Brian O'Driscoll and a try scoring by Geordan Murphy and Peter Stringer in the second half. Ireland led after 10 minutes, with Denis Hickie's try cutting it to 18-12. Italy had a strong defence but were not able to score early on. They took control of the game through Luciano Orquera's penalty after seven minutes. The hosts' core players included two fly-half players and a scrum-half player, led by Ronan O’Gara. Ireland's core players included center Gordon D'Arcy and wing Shane Horgan.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Ireland defeated Italy with two late tries by Murphy and Stringer as Brian O'Driscoll's breaks secured the win. Italy dominated early but struggled to score, while Ireland had a solid performance throughout despite penalties mishaps.
qwen2.5:3b:
Italy 17-28 Ireland  
Ireland's victory was driven by Brian O'Driscoll's creative plays, which set up tries for Geordan Murphy and Peter Stringer. Italy briefly led 9-8 early in the second half but were outscored with Denis Hickie scoring a try. Early Irish pressure forced penalties from Italian fly-half Luciano Orquera, who missed both kicks. O'Driscoll's outside break set up Stringer’s try, and later Ireland took a 18-12 lead through a try by Hickie which secured the victory despite Italy's late flurry of attacks.

tinyllama:1.1b: After a frustrating first half against Italy, Ireland had to overcome a slow start to get their workmanlike victory over the Italians, thanks to Brian O'Druscoll and an unexpected combination of skillful passes by Irish players. The game began with a bang, as Ireland opened up their lead through two tries in quick succession. However, Italy came back strongly and threatened to pull ahead before Ireland made a dramatic comeback thanks to the efforts of Shane Horan and a crucial try-alongside for captain Denis Hiicki. The final whistle signaled the end of the game as both teams played out an exciting and well-played match, ending in a 32-28 victory for Ireland.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The sum of three men was a lot greater than the two.
phi:2.7b: The game between Italy and Ireland was a thrilling victory for the Irish team led by captain Brian O'Driscoll. They secured the win with two crucial outside breaks from Geordan Murphy and Peter Stringer, followed by Denis Hickie's try which secured the lead in the second half. Despite missing a penalty and being on the receiving end of dangerous attacks, Ireland managed to hold their ground until the final quarter when Italy launched a flurry of efforts. O'Driscoll limped off with an injury but his contribution throughout the game was invaluable.
orca-mini:3b: Italy defeated Ireland 18-12 in a low-scoring match with two tries from Ireland captain Brian O'Driscoll and a penalty from Ronan O'Gara. Italy was able to draw within striking distance in the second half due to missed kicks by Ireland's Ronan O'Gara. The only highlight for Ireland was a powerful run by Brian O'Driscoll that led to a try for Peter Stringer. However, Ireland's star player, Shane Horgan, struggled to make an impact and was ultimately substituted. Italy's Martin Castrogiovanni scored the game-winning try in the dying minutes of the match.
hermes3:3b: Ireland beat Italy 28-18 in rugby match, guided by Brian O'Driscoll's two tries.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Ireland won against Italy with a score of 25-18, thanks to two magical moments from Brian O'Driscoll: outside breaks that set up tries for Geordan Murphy and Peter Stringer. Although Italy led early in the second half, Stringer's try gave Ireland the lead they never lost. Denis Hickie scored a try near the end of the game, ensuring an Irish victory. Despite nearly scoring through Ludovico Nitoglia, Italy struggled throughout against the Irish defense. O'Driscoll later limped off the field, joining Gordon D'Arcy on the sidelines.

Italy initially led 9-8 early in the second half, but O'Driscoll's outside breaks set up tries for Geordan Murphy and Peter Stringer, giving Ireland a lead they never relinquished. Italy threatened late, with Ludovico Nitoglia nearly scoring, but Denis Hickie's try sealed the win. Luciano Orquera and Roland de Marigny contributed penalties for Italy, while Ronan O'Gara added points for Ireland. Despite Italy's strong forward play, Ireland's backs proved decisive, with O'Driscoll's creativity making the difference. Martin Castrogiovanni scored a late consolation try for Italy.
stablelm2:1.6b: In a hard-fought match between Ireland and Italy, Brian O'Driscoll led Ireland to a crucial victory with two outside breaks that set up tries for Geordan Murphy and Peter Stringer. Despite Italy's early lead, Ireland managed to level the score with a penalty from Ronan O'Gara in the second half. Denis Hickie then secured an Irish win with a late try, after Italy nearly scored through Ludovico Nitoglia. The final Italian scores came from Martin Castrogiovanni and a try awarded for their pack's efforts throughout the match. Ireland dominated the majority of possession but struggled to secure any clear opportunities in the first half.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
Ireland secured a 28-17 victory over Italy in their rugby match, bolstered by two exceptional outside breaks from captain Brian O'Driscoll that led to tries for Geordan Murphy and Peter Stringer. Despite early leading by Orquera's penalty, Italy dominated the first half due to relentless pressure on Ireland's defense. O'Driscoll's sparking break set up both scores for Ireland, while Ronan O'Gara converted one and missed a kick that could have tied the game.

The match tightened in the second half as Italy narrowed the gap to 18-12 through Nitoglia's near-try. However, Denis Hickie's try with 10 minutes remaining sealed Ireland's win. O'Driscoll and Gordon D'Arcy limped off late in the game, but Ireland held on as Italy threatened with a driving maul. Martin Castrogiovanni scored a consolation try for Italy after full-time.
